t: Proverbs 16
The*p preparations of the heart in man, and the answer of the tongue, is from the Lord.*s
All*p the ways of a man are clean in his own eyes; but the Lord*s weigheth the spirits.
Commit*p thy works unto the Lord,*s and thy thoughts shall be established.
The*p Lord*s hath made all things for himself: yea, even the wicked for the day of evil.
Every*p one that is proud in heart is an abomination to the Lord:*s though hand join in hand, he shall not be unpunished.
By*p mercy and truth iniquity is purged: and by the fear of the Lord*s men depart from evil.
When*p a man's ways please the Lord,*s he maketh even his enemies to be at peace with him.
Better*p is a little with righteousness than great revenues without right.
A*p man's heart deviseth his way: but the Lord*s directeth his steps.
A*p divine sentence is in the lips of the king: his mouth transgresseth not in judgment.
A*p just weight and balance are the Lord's:*s all the weights of the bag are his work.
It*p is an abomination to kings to commit wickedness: for the throne is established by righteousness.
Righteous*p lips are the delight of kings; and they love him that speaketh right.
The*p wrath of a king is as messengers of death: but a wise man will pacify it.
In*p the light of the king's countenance is life; and his favour is as a cloud of the latter rain.
How*p much better is it to get wisdom than gold! and to get understanding rather to be chosen than silver!
The*p highway of the upright is to depart from evil: he that keepeth his way preserveth his soul.
Pride*p goeth before destruction, and an haughty spirit before a fall.
Better*p it is to be of an humble spirit with the lowly, than to divide the spoil with the proud.
He*p that handleth a matter wisely shall find good: and whoso trusteth in the Lord,*s happy is he.
The*p wise in heart shall be called prudent: and the sweetness of the lips increaseth learning.
Understanding*p is a wellspring of life unto him that hath it: but the instruction of fools is folly.
The*p heart of the wise teacheth his mouth, and addeth learning to his lips.
Pleasant*p words are as an honeycomb, sweet to the soul, and health to the bones.
There*p is a way that seemeth right unto a man, but the end thereof are the ways of death.
He*p that laboureth laboureth for himself; for his mouth craveth it of him.
An*p ungodly man diggeth up evil: and in his lips there is as a burning fire.
A*p froward man soweth strife: and a whisperer separateth chief friends.
A*p violent man enticeth his neighbour, and leadeth him into the way that is not good.
He*p shutteth his eyes to devise froward things: moving his lips he bringeth evil to pass.
The*p hoary head is a crown of glory, if it be found in the way of righteousness.
He*p that is slow to anger is better than the mighty; and he that ruleth his spirit than he that taketh a city.
The*p lot is cast into the lap; but the whole disposing thereof is of the Lord.*s
